natural problem: A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement.  Each  pump will pump 8 gallons of water per minute.  If a cubic foot of water contains 7.5 gallons, how many minutes will it take  to pump all of the water out of the basement using the three  pumps?
natural solution: The height of the water initially in feet is $$(18 \text{ inches})/(12 \text{ inches/foot})=1.5\text{ feet}.$$ The amount of water in the basement initially is $$1.5\cdot24\cdot32=1152\text{ cubic feet}.$$ Converting this to gallons, we have $$(1152 \text{ ft}^3)\cdot(7.5 \text { gallons/ft}^3)=8640 \text{ gallons}.$$ If each pump can pump out 8 gallons of water per minute, then three pumps can pump out $8\cdot3=24$ gallons a minute.
So it will take $$(8640 \text{ gallons})/(24 \text{ gallons/minute})=\boxed{360}$$ minutes to pump out all the water.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes foot gallon minute :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * foot = 7.5 * gallon"
and h1 : "1 * minute = 8 * gallon"
and h2 : "3 * pumps = 1 * minute"
and h3 : "24 * 32 * 1.5 * foot = 3 * pumps"
shows  "pumps = 360"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement.  Each  pump will pump 8 gallons of water per minute.  If a cubic foot of water contains 7.5 gallons, how many minutes will it take  to pump all of the water out of the basement using the three  pumps? The final Answer is 360
 ### Proof
 The height of the water initially in feet is $$(18 \text{ inches})/(12 \text{ inches/foot})=1.5\text{ feet}.$$ The amount of water in the basement initially is $$1.5\cdot24\cdot32=1152\text{ cubic feet}.$$ Converting this to gallons, we have $$(1152 \text{ ft}^3)\cdot(7.5 \text { gallons/ft}^3)=8640 \text{ gallons}.$$ If each pump can pump out 8 gallons of water per minute, then three pumps can pump out $8\cdot3=24$ gallons a minute.
 So it will take $$(8640 \text{ gallons})/(24 \text{ gallons/minute})=\boxed{360}$$ minutes to pump out all the water.
 *)

theorem
fixes foot gallon minute :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * foot = 7.5 * gallon"
and h1 : "1 * minute = 8 * gallon"
and h2 : "3 * pumps = 1 * minute"
and h3 : "24 * 32 * 1.5 * foot = 3 * pumps"
shows  "pumps = 360"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A pump can fill a tank with water in a certain amount of time. If one foot of the tank is equivalent to 7.5 gallons of water and one minute of pumping fills 8 gallons, and three pumps take one minute to fill the tank, how many pumps are required if the tank is 24 feet by 32 feet by 1.5 feet? The final answer is 360 pumps.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes gallons_per_minute pumps minutes :: real
assumes h0 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h1 : "pumps = 3"
and h2 : "minutes = (24 * 32 * 1.5 * 7.5) / (gallons_per_minute * pumps)"
shows  "minutes = 360"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement.  Each  pump will pump 8 gallons of water per minute.  If a cubic foot of water contains 7.5 gallons, how many minutes will it take  to pump all of the water out of the basement using the three  pumps? The final Answer is 360
 ### Proof
 The height of the water initially in feet is $$(18 \text{ inches})/(12 \text{ inches/foot})=1.5\text{ feet}.$$ The amount of water in the basement initially is $$1.5\cdot24\cdot32=1152\text{ cubic feet}.$$ Converting this to gallons, we have $$(1152 \text{ ft}^3)\cdot(7.5 \text { gallons/ft}^3)=8640 \text{ gallons}.$$ If each pump can pump out 8 gallons of water per minute, then three pumps can pump out $8\cdot3=24$ gallons a minute.
 So it will take $$(8640 \text{ gallons})/(24 \text{ gallons/minute})=\boxed{360}$$ minutes to pump out all the water.
 *)

theorem
fixes gallons_per_minute pumps minutes :: real
assumes h0 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h1 : "pumps = 3"
and h2 : "minutes = (24 * 32 * 1.5 * 7.5) / (gallons_per_minute * pumps)"
shows  "minutes = 360"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Three pumps, each with a flow rate of 8 gallons per minute, are used to fill a pool. If the pool has a capacity of 24 * 32 * 1.5 * 7.5 gallons, how long does it take to fill the pool? The final answer is 360 minutes.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pumps gallons_per_minute cubic_feet_per_gallon area depth :: real
assumes h0 : "pumps = 3"
and h1 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h2 : "cubic_feet_per_gallon = 7.5"
and h3 : "area = 24*32"
and h4 : "depth = 18 / 12"
shows  "(area * depth * cubic_feet_per_gallon) / (pumps * gallons_per_minute) = 360"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement. The final Answer is 360

 So it will take $$(8640 \text{ gallons})/(24 \text{ gallons/minute})=\boxed{360}$$ minutes to pump out all the water.
 *)

theorem
fixes pumps gallons_per_minute cubic_feet_per_gallon area depth :: real
assumes h0 : "pumps = 3"

and h3 : "area = 24*32"
and h4 : "depth = 18 / 12"
shows  "(area * depth * cubic_feet_per_gallon) / (pumps * gallons_per_minute) = 360"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Three pumps, each with a capacity of 8 gallons per minute, are used to fill a swimming pool of area 24 feet by 32 feet and depth of 1.5 feet. If there are 7.5 cubic feet of water in each gallon, how long in minutes will it take to fill the pool? The final answer is 360 minutes.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes gallons_per_minute :: real
and gallons_per_cubic_foot :: real
and area :: real
and depth :: real
and pumps :: int
assumes h0 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h1 : "gallons_per_cubic_foot = 7.5"
and h2 : "area = 24 * 32"
and h3 : "depth = 18 / 12"
and h4 : "pumps = 3"
shows  "(area * depth * gallons_per_cubic_foot) / (gallons_per_minute * pumps) = 360"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement. The final Answer is 360

 So it will take $$(8640 \text{ gallons})/(24 \text{ gallons/minute})=\boxed{360}$$ minutes to pump out all the water.
 *)

theorem
fixes gallons_per_minute :: real
and gallons_per_cubic_foot :: real
and area :: real
and depth :: real
and pumps :: int
assumes h0 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h1 : "gallons_per_cubic_foot = 7.5"
and h2 : "area = 24 * 32"
and h3 : "depth = 18 / 12"
and h4 : "pumps = 3"
shows  "(area * depth * gallons_per_cubic_foot) / (gallons_per_minute * pumps) = 360"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A pool with an area of 24 feet by 32 feet and a depth of 18 inches is being filled by 3 pumps, each of which can pump water at a rate of 8 gallons per minute. If there are 7.5 gallons in each cubic foot of water, how long in minutes will it take to fill the pool? The final answer is 360 minutes.

fixes pumps gallons_per_minute time :: real
assumes h0 : "pumps = 3"
and h1 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h2 : "time = (24 * 32 * 1.5) * 7.5 / (pumps * gallons_per_minute)"

a_4.informal problem: Three pumps, each with a capacity of 8 gallons per minute, are used to fill a tank. If the tank can hold 24*32*1.5 cubic feet of water and a cubic foot of water is approximately 7.5 gallons, how many minutes will it take to fill the tank? The final answer is 360 minutes.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pumps gallons_per_minute volume_in_cubic_feet volume_in_gallons :: real
assumes h0 : "pumps = 3"
and h1 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h2 : "volume_in_cubic_feet = 24 * 32 * 1.5"
and h3 : "volume_in_gallons = volume_in_cubic_feet * 7.5"
shows  "volume_in_gallons / (pumps * gallons_per_minute) = 360"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement. a_5.informal problem: If there are three pumps each pumping 8 gallons of water per minute, how long (in minutes) would it take to fill a tank with a volume of 24ft x 32ft x 1.5ft. Note that 1 cubic foot of water is approximately 7.5 gallons. The final answer is 360 minutes.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes gallons_per_minute :: real
assumes h0 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h1 : "1 cubic_foot = 7.5 gallons"
and h2 : "1 foot = 12 inches"
and h3 : "1 basement = 24 * 32 * (18 / h2) cubic_foot"
and h4 : "1 pump = gallons_per_minute / h1 cubic_foot_per_minute"
and h5 : "3 pumps = 3 * h4 cubic_foot_per_minute"
shows  "h3 / h5 = 360 minutes"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement.  Each  pump will pump 8 gallons of water per minute.  If a cubic foot of water contains 7.5 gallons, how many minutes will it take  to pump all of the water out of the basement using the three  pumps? The final Answer is 360
 ### Proof
 The height of the water initially in feet is $$(18 \text{ inches})/(12 \text{ inches/foot})=1.5\text{ feet}.$$ The amount of water in the basement initially is $$1.5\cdot24\cdot32=1152\text{ cubic feet}.$$ Converting this to gallons, we have $$(1152 \text{ ft}^3)\cdot(7.5 \text { gallons/ft}^3)=8640 \text{ gallons}.$$ If each pump can pump out 8 gallons of water per minute, then three pumps can pump out $8\cdot3=24$ gallons a minute.
 So it will take $$(8640 \text{ gallons})/(24 \text{ gallons/minute})=\boxed{360}$$ minutes to pump out all the water.
 *)

theorem
fixes gallons_per_minute :: real
assumes h0 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h1 : "1 cubic_foot = 7.5 gallons"
and h2 : "1 foot = 12 inches"
and h3 : "1 basement = 24 * 32 * (18 / h2) cubic_foot"
and h4 : "1 pump = gallons_per_minute / h1 cubic_foot_per_minute"
and h5 : "3 pumps = 3 * h4 cubic_foot_per_minute"
shows  "h3 / h5 = 360 minutes"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A basement has dimensions 24 feet by 32 feet by 18 inches. If one pump can pump water at a rate of 8 gallons per minute, and 1 cubic foot of water is approximately 7.5 gallons, how long will it take for three of these pumps to pump out all the water in the basement? The final answer is 360 minutes.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes basement_area :: real
and water_depth :: real
and pump_rate :: real
and pumps :: nat
and water_volume :: real
and time :: real
assumes h0 : "basement_area = 24 * 32"
and h1 : "water_depth = 18 / 12"
and h2 : "pump_rate = 8"
and h3 : "pumps = 3"
and h4 : "water_volume = basement_area * water_depth * 7.5"
and h5 : "time = water_volume / (pump_rate * pumps)"
shows  "time = 360"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement.  Each  pump will pump 8 gallons of water per minute.  If a cubic foot of water contains 7.5 gallons, how many minutes will it take  to pump all of the water out of the basement using the three  pumps? The final Answer is 360
 ### Proof
 The height of the water initially in feet is $$(18 \text{ inches})/(12 \text{ inches/foot})=1.5\text{ feet}.$$ The amount of water in the basement initially is $$1.5\cdot24\cdot32=1152\text{ cubic feet}.$$ Converting this to gallons, we have $$(1152 \text{ ft}^3)\cdot(7.5 \text { gallons/ft}^3)=8640 \text{ gallons}.$$ If each pump can pump out 8 gallons of water per minute, then three pumps can pump out $8\cdot3=24$ gallons a minute.
 So it will take $$(8640 \text{ gallons})/(24 \text{ gallons/minute})=\boxed{360}$$ minutes to pump out all the water.
 *)

theorem
fixes basement_area :: real
and water_depth :: real
and pump_rate :: real
and pumps :: nat
and water_volume :: real
and time :: real
assumes h0 : "basement_area = 24 * 32"
and h1 : "water_depth = 18 / 12"
and h2 : "pump_rate = 8"
and h3 : "pumps = 3"
and h4 : "water_volume = basement_area * water_depth * 7.5"
and h5 : "time = water_volume / (pump_rate * pumps)"
shows  "time = 360"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A flooded basement with an area of 24 feet by 32 feet has water at a depth of 18 inches. If three pumps, each capable of pumping 8 gallons of water per minute, are used to remove the water, how many minutes will it take to remove all the water, given that one cubic foot of water is approximately 7.5 gallons? The answer is 360 minutes.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pumps gallons_per_minute gallons_per_cubic_foot :: real
and basement_length basement_width water_depth :: real
assumes h0 : "pumps = 3"
and h1 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h2 : "gallons_per_cubic_foot = 7.5"
and h3 : "basement_length = 24"
and h4 : "basement_width = 32"
and h5 : "water_depth = 1.5"
and h6 : "gallons_per_minute * pumps = 
            (basement_length * basement_width * water_depth * gallons_per_cubic_foot) / x"
shows  "x = 360"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement.  Each  pump will pump 8 gallons of water per minute.  If a cubic foot of water contains 7.5 gallons, how many minutes will it take  to pump all of the water out of the basement using the three  pumps? The final Answer is 360
 ### Proof
 The height of the water initially in feet is $$(18 \text{ inches})/(12 \text{ inches/foot})=1.5\text{ feet}.$$ The amount of water in the basement initially is $$1.5\cdot24\cdot32=1152\text{ cubic feet}.$$ Converting this to gallons, we have $$(1152 \text{ ft}^3)\cdot(7.5 \text { gallons/ft}^3)=8640 \text{ gallons}.$$ If each pump can pump out 8 gallons of water per minute, then three pumps can pump out $8\cdot3=24$ gallons a minute.
 So it will take $$(8640 \text{ gallons})/(24 \text{ gallons/minute})=\boxed{360}$$ minutes to pump out all the water.
 *)

theorem
fixes pumps gallons_per_minute gallons_per_cubic_foot :: real
and basement_length basement_width water_depth :: real
assumes h0 : "pumps = 3"
and h1 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h2 : "gallons_per_cubic_foot = 7.5"
and h3 : "basement_length = 24"
and h4 : "basement_width = 32"
and h5 : "water_depth = 1.5"
and h6 : "gallons_per_minute * pumps = 
            (basement_length * basement_width * water_depth * gallons_per_cubic_foot) / x"
shows  "x = 360"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There are three pumps in a basement, each of which can pump out 8 gallons of water per minute. The basement, which is 24 feet long and 32 feet wide, has been flooded with a depth of 1.5 feet of water. Given that there are 7.5 gallons of water in a cubic foot, find out how many minutes it would take for the pumps to remove all the water from the basement. The answer is 360 minutes.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes gallons_per_minute pump_speed :: real
and pump_count :: int
and area basement_depth gallons_per_cubic_feet :: real
and time :: real
assumes h0 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h1 : "pump_speed = gallons_per_minute * pump_count"
and h2 : "area = 24 * 32"
and h3 : "basement_depth = 18 / 12"
and h4 : "gallons_per_cubic_feet = 7.5"
and h5 : "time = ((area * basement_depth * gallons_per_cubic_feet) / pump_speed)"
shows  "time = 360"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A basement has a 24-foot by 32-foot rectangular floor. The basement is flooded with water to a depth of 18 inches. Three pumps are used to pump the water out of the basement.  Each  pump will pump 8 gallons of water per minute.  If a cubic foot of water contains 7.5 gallons, how many minutes will it take  to pump all of the water out of the basement using the three  pumps? The final Answer is 360
 ### Proof
 The height of the water initially in feet is $$(18 \text{ inches})/(12 \text{ inches/foot})=1.5\text{ feet}.$$ The amount of water in the basement initially is $$1.5\cdot24\cdot32=1152\text{ cubic feet}.$$ Converting this to gallons, we have $$(1152 \text{ ft}^3)\cdot(7.5 \text { gallons/ft}^3)=8640 \text{ gallons}.$$ If each pump can pump out 8 gallons of water per minute, then three pumps can pump out $8\cdot3=24$ gallons a minute.
 So it will take $$(8640 \text{ gallons})/(24 \text{ gallons/minute})=\boxed{360}$$ minutes to pump out all the water.
 *)

theorem
fixes gallons_per_minute pump_speed :: real
and pump_count :: int
and area basement_depth gallons_per_cubic_feet :: real
and time :: real
assumes h0 : "gallons_per_minute = 8"
and h1 : "pump_speed = gallons_per_minute * pump_count"
and h2 : "area = 24 * 32"
and h3 : "basement_depth = 18 / 12"
and h4 : "gallons_per_cubic_feet = 7.5"
and h5 : "time = ((area * basement_depth * gallons_per_cubic_feet) / pump_speed)"
shows  "time = 360"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If a pump can move 8 gallons of water per minute, and you have multiple pumps working together, how long would it take to empty a flooded basement that is 24 feet by 32 feet and flooded to a depth of 18 inches? The final answer is 360 minutes.
